LG.L: MARK! how the cooing pair draws near!
Why, Captain?
—Emily!
—I'm here!
Where are you? Here in half-drown'd state!
Hark, the old ring-dove calls his mate!

SP.SPEAKER: MEDLEY.
SP.P: And now, Matt, must you avoid an untimely explana∣tion.
SP.STAGE: [Sir Walter, and Miss Di return, and first discover each other, with astonishment, as Capt. O'Donnel advances between them unbuttoning his lapels, and carelessly throwing the rain off his hat.

SP.SPEAKER: CAPT. O'DONNEL.
SP.P: What a mighty pretty joke is love in a shower! [Looking at them alternately.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR WALTER.
SP.P: Upon my soul—Madam!—I—can't say—that—that I expected the honor of this ducking—to—to meet you here!—

SP.SPEAKER: MISS DI.—(Confused.)
SP.P: Nor I—sir—the pleasure of catching my death, for the—the—felicity of seeing you here!—Provoking wretch!— (Aside.)—You may think, sir—

SP.SPEAKER: CAPT. O'DONNEL.
SP.P: Oh, palliluh!—I did not hope for the honor of ex∣pecting you here—nor I the pleasure of seeing you there— (imitating them)—when you had both contrived the whole farce beforehand—except the happiness of seeing my own self—any where!

SP.SPEAKER: MISS DI.
SP.P: This is very extraordinary behaviour in you, sir! [To Capt. O'Donnel.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR WALTER.
SP.P: And have I caught you out, Cousin Prudery, at last? [Exultingly.

SP.SPEAKER: MISS DI.
SP.P: What is it you mean, sir?—I came—

SP.SPEAKER: SIR WALTER.
SP.P: To learn to pick hops according to the articles of war!—but you've got a good sopping for't—and so forth. [Aside to her.

SP.SPEAKER: CAPT. O'DONNEL.
SP.P: There's an honest fellow in the world, Madam, who has reason to expect better usage at your hands.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR WALTER.
SP.P: Excellent!—What say you to that, Coz?—Tho' she has flushed my pretty game—I can match her—for now I shall be able to silence her clapper—by positive evi∣dence of the fact! [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: MISS DI.
SP.P: To you, sir, I hope I shall find time to explain my∣self; and as to my cousin Wiseacre—

SP.SPEAKER: CAPT. O'DONNEL.
SP.P: Oh, Madam, the thing is bad enough without any further explanation.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR WALTER.
SP.P: And pray, sir, who may you be—that come in this impudent, blustering manner, to poach after a part of my family?

SP.SPEAKER: CAPT. O'DONNEL.
SP.P:
Part of your family?—That's a good joke, my old boy!— (laughing.)—but I'll soon settle that.—As you're such a dev'lish fighting fellow—d'ye see—why, you may be pleas'd to give me a little account your own self—
for daring to presume, to seduce the mistress of my friend.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR WALTER.—(Amazed.)
SP.P: I seduce!—I—a fighting fellow!

SP.SPEAKER: CAPT. O'DONNEL.
SP.P: Come, come—make no more words about it:—you'll meet me, my old buck, without further ceremony, on this very spot, to-morrow morning, at sun-set—that I may not be compell'd to post you—upon ev'ry pole in your own hop-ground.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR WALTER.—(Looking inquisitively at him.)
SP.P: Damme, if I think this fellow's any thing but a bully after all!—I'll try him, however— (Aside.)—Look ye, Captain Bounceabout!—I have served three cam∣paigns, in our county militia, with some credit!—and, let me tell you, sir—I am no more afraid than you, or any other man—of sire! sword!—and so forth!

SP.SPEAKER: CAPT. O'DONNEL.
SP.P: So much the better, my dear.

LG.HEAD: AIR XXIX.— DUET.

LG.L: THE dreadful weapons choose, sir!
No, that I must refuse, sir;
We'll bring enough,
Then sight in buff,
'Twill make important news, sir!
Sword! pike! and hand-grenade!
Will prove us not afraid,
O'Don. With these try well to hack me;
Sir Walt. With these you think to hack me;
But being brave,
I'll only have
—My honor's self to back me!
—Twelve constables

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE XVI.
DIV2.STAGE: MEDLEY alone, in an Archery Dress, with a Bugle Horn.

SP.SPEAKER: MEDLEY.—(Laughing.)
SP.P: What would I give, to know how they've settled their matters?—but we shall have it piping hot when Miss Di comes on the forest, I'll warrant it!—Now to mus∣ter my female troop.

SP.SPEAKER: BOB.
SP.P: Here they come, brother Matt—and a pretty shew they make, sure enough!—
SP.STAGE: (Female Archers trip in, pro∣ceded by forest colours—and a pastoral band of music.)

SP.SPEAKER: MEDLEY.
SP.P: Well, my sprightly lasses!—now fall in—and we'll soon march off to the Oak—and see who's to win the pretty prize heifer.

LG.HEAD: AIR XXX.— SESTETTO.
LG.L: Oh sweet Mr. Medley, I say!
But mind Mr. Medley, I say!
Come dear Mr. Medley, I say!
What the deuce is the matter?
How neatly they prattle!
If you keep such a clatter,
What sweet pretty prattle!
No game on the forest will stay,
—Oh sie!
But hence it will fly.
To Old Nick in a trice to get out of your way!
Oh sweet Mr. Medley, I say!
But mind Mr. Medley, I say!
Come dear Mr. Medley, I say!
Now don't stretch your lungs—
We mind not your sneers:
For to all your glib tongues
Little Husseys you know,
Come, pray let us go!
I've only but one pair of ears!
—Pretty dears!

SP.P: "But I say, Mr. Medley!"—"Now, dear Mr. Medley!" &c. &c. &c.

SP.SPEAKER: MEDLEY.
SP.P: Halloah!—why, if you keep up this clatter, I tell you again, that all the game will break the bbounds of the forest!—
"Ay, but Mr. Medley—suppose I say, Mr. Medley, &c. &c.

SP.SPEAKER: MEDLEY.
SP.P: "Now pray talk a little gently, sweet ones!
SP.STAGE: ["Bob, and Kitty Maple, looking at the colours, inscribed IN MEDIO PALMA."]

SP.SPEAKER: BOB.
SP.P: "An't they very gay, and pretty?

SP.SPEAKER: KITTY.
SP.P: "Yes, very smart indeed!

SP.SPEAKER: BOB.
SP.P: "They were done, spick and span new, at London!

SP.SPEAKER: KITTY.
SP.P: "Ay—but what's the signification of the gold wri∣ting, Mr. Bob?

SP.SPEAKER: BOB.
SP.P: "Oh! that's our Vicar's doings—it's Arabac, I believe—but ask my brother Matt—he can tell you all about it.—

SP.SPEAKER: KITTY.
SP.P: "So I will.—Mr. Medley, what does this here mean? [Pointing to the Motto.

SP.SPEAKER: MEDLEY.
SP.P: "That there, my love?

SP.SPEAKER: KITTY.
SP.P: "Yes, that—

SP.SPEAKER: MEDLEY.
SP.P: "Why, as to Archery, it means—that—if—but, per∣haps, you'd like a free translation best?

SP.SPEAKER: KITTY.
SP.P: "Dear! I don't care!

SP.SPEAKER: MEDLEY.
SP.P: "Why then the plain meaning is that,—the middle's your mark!—Now for it, girls!—come, Kitty Maple, stand you to the right.— (Places her.)—You ought to shoot well, hussey—for your father was always a dead hand at pulling the long bow—

SP.SPEAKER: KITTY.
SP.P: "I wonder you an't asham'd of your wicked self!"

SP.SPEAKER: MEDLEY.
SP.P: Here, Betsy Blewit—stand by the side of her—very well.—Scky Wheatsheaf, and Jenny Whitethorn, you are next—now let the rest drop in—two and two.—But where the deuce are the little woodside nymphs?

SP.SPEAKER: BOB.
SP.P: I'll go and fetch 'em, brother.

SP.SPEAKER: MEDLEY.
SP.P: Do, Bob!—tell 'em they'll be too late, if they don't put their best foot first.

SP.SPEAKER: KITTY.
SP.P: Somebody, I see, thinks there'll be no sport, if some folks an't here!

SP.SPEAKER: MEDLEY.
SP.P: Smartly said, Kitty!—I don't know how they may shoot an arrow—but you must take care, or some folks will hit as far with their sparklers, as the best of you!—Now strike up, pipers!—

LG.L: COME lasses! Follow me,
With merry glee,
To sports of Woodland Archery!
With merry glee,
We follow thee,
To sports of Woodland Archery!

SP.STAGE: [Medley puts himself at their head, and they march off to the repeat of the Chorus.

SP.SPEAKER: DOLLY.
SP.P: Dear, dear!—what can I do?—We shall certainly be too late!—and you will not go?— (Speaking to Emi∣ly behind)—How can you be so unkind?

SP.SPEAKER: BOB.
SP.P:
Come! come! my pretty ones—they are all march∣ed to the ground—with music and streamers!—and by
this time her Ladyship, Miss Dinah, is there!—Matt sent me to look for you!—But where's Miss Emily?

SP.SPEAKER: DOLLY.
SP.P: There she sits under that tree—and won't budge an inch, for all I can say to her!

SP.SPEAKER: EMILY.
SP.P: I beg you to excuse me, Dolly!—let me go back—say I am unwell!—

SP.SPEAKER: BOB.
SP.P: Now, pray you, Miss Emily, come along with us—the sight will be worth nothing without you!

SP.SPEAKER: EMILY.
SP.P: Well, since you will have it so—proceed—
SP.STAGE: [Sound of a Bugle horn, within the Forest.

LG.HEAD: AIR XXXII.— GLEE.
LG.L: HARK—the Bugle's sylvan strain,
Calls us to the sportive plain,
Scene of artless love!
Shepherds—faithful tales advancing,
Maidens hearts in transport dancing,
Happy may they prove!
How blissful then the Wood-nymphs green retreat,
Where Love, and Innocence enraptur'd meet!

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE XX.
DIV2.STAGE: Tents—Targets—Forest Colours, &c.—Female Archers, &c. ranged on each Wing—A Dance, in Character, commences on Miss Di Clackit's entering, and taking her Seat at the Front of the Forest.—At the Close of the Dance, Medley winds his Bugle Horn, and the Female Archers take their respective Posts.

SP.SPEAKER: MISS DI.—(Walking down thro' the ranks.)
SP.P: Are they all here?—are they all ready?—"I'm so flurried, and confused! [To Medley apart.

SP.SPEAKER: MEDLEY.
SP.P: "What's the matter, Ma'am?

SP.SPEAKER: MISS DI.
SP.P: "Would you think it?—My blundering Cousin has discover'd me in the hop-ground!

SP.SPEAKER: MEDLEY.
SP.P: "Why, that was a little awkward, to be sure—but I can manage it, Ma'am—by swearing, that I sent you there on purpose to meet him!

SP.SPEAKER: MISS DI.
SP.P: "My dear Medley—can you, indeed—can you, indeed?—but then if he—

SP.SPEAKER: MEDLEY.
SP.P: "Oh! never trouble yourself about it—to be sure I can—and with a pretty safe conscience, I fancy! [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: MISS DI.
SP.P: "As to the Captain—I can easily set him right my∣self—but I wonder he's not here.— (Walks towards the Female Archers.)—You've pick'd a tolerable set—tole∣rable set!—Hold up your head, girl—hold up your head!" [To one of the Female Archers.

SP.SPEAKER: MEDLEY.
SP.P: All ready—quite ready, Madam.—Where the deuce can my little hussies be? [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: MISS DI.
SP.P: As they are already—you may sound the charge, and let the archery commence; though I don't know—

SP.SPEAKER: DOLLY.—(To Emily.)
SP.P: That's her Ladyship, Sir Walter's cousin, sitting alone!
SP.STAGE: [Medley observes them, as the two first Archers stand forth.]

SP.SPEAKER: MEDLEY.
SP.P: Oh, you're come at last!—but you've lost your turns—so stay here, Dolly, till I call you—for I must attend the targets.— (The shooting commences cross-ways at tar∣gets placed on each side of the Oak.—Medley holding in his hand a card, on which to mark the different shots.)

SP.SPEAKER: MEDLEY.—(After the first shots.)
SP.P:
Pretty well, Kitty—but levell'd a little too high!—Better, much better, Betsey Blewitt—just within the
third circle!—very well, indeed!— (After two other shots.)—Oh, bad, very bad!— (Two others.)—Excel∣lent!—Well done, Jenny!—within three inches of the bull's eye!—Let me see who'll beat that?

SP.SPEAKER: MISS DI.
SP.P: Who's nearest, Medley?—who's nearest?—who's nearest?

SP.SPEAKER: MEDLEY.
SP.P: Oh, Madam, Jenny Hawthorn! hollow!— (Shews Miss Di the mark'd card:—while the Female Archers march to music for their arrows, and return to different sides.)

SP.SPEAKER: MEDLEY.
SP.P: Now for it, Dolly—Now, Dolly!

SP.SPEAKER: MISS DI.
SP.P: Don't rattle and talk so fast, Medley—you confuse 'em—you confuse 'em—besides, if they—

SP.SPEAKER: MEDLEY.
SP.P: Oh, worst of all, Dolly!—No heifer for you, Doll—but you think a good husband prize enough for one day, I suppose? [To her aside.

SP.SPEAKER: DOLLY.
SP.P: Of all conscience, Matt—I'm content!

DIV2.STAGE: Enter WILFORD and CAPT. O'DONNEL, near the Oak.

SP.SPEAKER: WILFORD.
SP.P: Where is the perfidious Emily?

SP.SPEAKER: CAPT. O'DONNEL.
SP.P: Oh, there she sits— (Pointing to Miss Di)—just as unconcerned—as if nothing had happen'd at all!

SP.SPEAKER: WILFORD.
SP.STAGE: (Walking towards Miss Di, starts back!—turning to O'Donnel)
SP.P: Why add mockery to my distress?

SP.SPEAKER: MISS DI.
SP.P: Oh, the Captain's here!—I'll pretend not to observe him. [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: MEDLEY.—(On Emily advancing to shoot.)
SP.P: Don't be alarm'd, there's a dear.

SP.SPEAKER: CAPT. O'DONNEL.
SP.P: But here's a creature, Wilford—here's one— (beckon∣ing to Wilford)—after my own choice. [At this instant Emily shoots—and hits the centre of the target.—Bugle sounds.

SP.SPEAKER: MEDLEY.
SP.P: She's won it—she's won it!

LG.HEAD: AIR XXXIII.— CHORUS.
LG.L: TO Beauty's shaft the prize decree,
In strains of antient minstrelsy!

SP.STAGE: [Wilford and Emily at this instant behold each other—she sinks on Dolly's arm—Capt. O'Donnel runs and sup∣ports her.

SP.SPEAKER: WILFORD.
SP.P: Can it be possible?

SP.SPEAKER: CAPT. O'DONNEL.
SP.P: Oh! very possible! keep a little back.— (To Wil∣ford.)—It's only a small flutteration at seeing me—'twill soon be over—see how she revives, at the sound of my own voice!

SP.SPEAKER: WILFORD.
SP.P: Oh, my Emily!

SP.SPEAKER: EMILY.
SP.P: And do I live again to behold my faithful Wilford?

SP.SPEAKER: MEDLEY.
SP.P: Oh, oh! the pretty lost lamb's own'd at last!—the plot will unravel fast—I must to Sir Walter, and by a full consession, secure a free pardon.

SP.SPEAKER: MISS DI.—(Drawing near.)
SP.P: What is the matter?—what is the cause of this con∣fusion?—Pray, sir—how have I deserved this usage? am I so alter'd that you don't recollect me—don't recollect me? Surely, Captain—

SP.SPEAKER: CAPT. O'DONNEL.
SP.P: Faith and troth—for the matter of that—tho' you have forgot yourself—I know you well enough, Miss Emily, and all your pranks!

SP.SPEAKER: MISS DI.
SP.P: Miss Emily?—all my pranks? What can he mean? what can he mean?—You well know, sir, my name is Dinah; and that I am the nearest relation of Sir Walter Waring—tho' you are all conspiring against my honor? but justice, I hope—

SP.SPEAKER: CAPT. O'DONNEL.
SP.P: Upon my conscience, I begin to fancy we are all as mad as wild geese! Harkee, Wilford, is it you, or me, that this bewitching rogue has beplundered out of our senses?

SP.SPEAKER: WILFORD.
SP.P: It is I, my friend, who have lost mine in love, and ad∣miration!

LG.L: OH tell me, Memory! no more,
What woe in banishment was mine—
What pain this lab'ring bosom bore,
Compell'd its treasure to resign!
But tell me, Memory—more kind,
The envy'd transports I regain;
Record them on my grateful mind,
That not a sorrow may remain!

SP.SPEAKER: WILFORD.
SP.P: But where is the rustic guardian of my Emily?

SP.SPEAKER: EMILY.
SP.P: Here— (Pointing to Fairlop.)—My kind, disinterested protector!

SP.SPEAKER: FAIRLOP.
SP.P: Lackaday! what is all this?

SP.SPEAKER: DOLLY.
SP.P: Oh, father!—Miss Emily's sweetheart's found, and this is he!

SP.SPEAKER: WILFORD.
SP.P: I wish I could express the obligations I owe to you.

SP.SPEAKER: FAIRLOP.
SP.P: Pooh! pooh! why do you give the gentleman all this trouble? May I be free enough to speak a word of my mind?

SP.SPEAKER: WILFORD.
SP.P: By all means!

SP.SPEAKER: FAIRLOP.
SP.P: Then, set you, sir, as much store by this treasure thro' life— (takes her hand)—as I have done but for three short months—and, trust a plain man, we shall all be sufficiently rewarded!

SP.SPEAKER: WILFORD.
SP.P: Generous woodman! Emily, you must prevail upon your adopted sister, to attend you to Wilford Lodge.

SP.SPEAKER: EMILY.
SP.P: What say you, my dear friend, Dolly?

SP.SPEAKER: MEDLEY.
SP.P: Oh! that's impossible, Ma'am—she may soon have a house full of children of her own to take care of! [Conceitedly.

SP.SPEAKER: EMILY.
SP.P: How is all this?

SP.SPEAKER: DOLLY.
SP.P: The audacious wretch coax'd me into a kind of pro∣mise this morning;—and I can't find in my heart to be worse than my word.

SP.SPEAKER: CAPT. O'DONNEL.
SP.P: Why then, give Dolly the little prize-cow, for a bride's portion—I think, Wilford, you'll not be after making a bull of that now.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter SIR WALTER, followed by Female Archers, &c.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR WALTER.
SP.P: Come along, come along! and see how I administer justice among 'em.—I arrest you all in my own name!—and so forth.

SP.SPEAKER: WILFORD.
SP.P: Pray, sir, what may be your charge against us?— (Smiling.)—It's a bailable offence, I trust?

SP.SPEAKER: SIR WALTER.
SP.P: Yes, if you put in your appearance at my house, where, with your consent, we'll have a merry night on't—and so forth. [Shaking Wilford by the hand.

SP.SPEAKER: DOLLY.
SP.P: But perhaps, Miss Emily—

SP.SPEAKER: SIR WALTER.
SP.P: Won't resist my authority, when she knows I've a chaplain at hand, who can soon bind her over to good behaviour for life.

SP.SPEAKER: CAPT. O'DONNEL.
SP.P: Upon my conscience, Sir Walter, but you may com∣mand Arthur O'Donnel, esquire.—Give me your hand, my old buck—it's a pleasanter thing to draw a cork, than a sword, with an honest fellow, at any time.—But hark ye, little Mittimus, there'll be no need for that Snap-dragon—Miss Consumption there, to be one of the party!

SP.SPEAKER: WILFORD.—(To Fairlop.)
SP.P: But, my best of friends, with your permission,—we'll transplant you to a larger farm, where you may acquire the means of extending your benevolence.

SP.SPEAKER: FAIRLOP.
SP.P: With thanks for your kindness, sir,—as my Land∣lord's ill-will is blown over, I'll live, and die by my na∣tive woodside! But, before you rob me and Dolly of our pretty companion, and depart—stop at our cottage by the way—and, if you can break bread with a lowly man—you shall have his blessing into the bargain.

LG.HEAD: CHORUS.
LG.L: TUNE the pipe, and strike the tabor,
Quickly join their faithful hands;
This is not a time for labour,
While young Joy on tip-toe stands!
JUSTICE bids me now befit you,
Blind to all your roguish charms;
So I'll certainly commit you—
To an honest husband's arms!
Tune the Pipe, &c.
Fearless now our vows are plighted,
Hence the clouds of sorrow fly!
Love, and constancy united,
Thus restore a tranquil sky.
Tune the Pipe, &c.
—Dolly—mind you love me dearly!
—Never fear if you are true:
—Scolding, I shall take but queerly,
—Chiding, I shall take but queerly,
—Sulky fits will never do!
Tune the pipe, &c.
Marriage faith's a pretty notion,
If you could but change a wife;
But a soldier loves promotion—
Not a warm campaign for life!
Tune the pipe, &c.
'Though my Woodland thus you plunder,
Of the sweetest plant that grew,
At the loss I cannot wonder—
May it better thrive with you.
Tune the pipe, and strike the tabor,
Quickly join their faithful hands;
This is not a time for labour,
While young Joy on tip-toe stands!

DIV1.HEAD: ADDITIONAL SONG, By the AUTHOR, introduced on Saturday in the Comic Opera of THE WOODMAN.

LG.L: Court me not to scenes of pleasure,
This fond heart no more must know;
Can it beat to Mirth's gay measure,
All its strings attun'd to woe?
No! the mind by Hope forsaken,
But of Sorrow seeks relief:
Joy no transport can awaken,
Sighs must number out its grief.
